q: What are the symptoms of a breast abscess?
a: Symptoms of a breast abscess may include: a lump or swelling in your breast, pain in your breast (it may also feel warm or look red), a high temperature, and feeling generally unwell.

q: What are other conditions that can cause breast soreness and swelling?
a: Other conditions that can cause breast soreness and swelling include breast pain and breast lumps.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for a possible breast abscess?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if you experience a painful, warm, or red breast, or if you have a lump or swelling in your breast.

q: What happens at a GP appointment for a breast abscess?
a: If the GP suspects a breast abscess, they will refer you to the hospital for an ultrasound scan to confirm the presence of an abscess.

q: What treatment is involved for a breast abscess?
a: Treatment for a breast abscess involves draining the pus from the abscess. This can be done with a needle or a small cut in the skin. Local anesthesia will be given to numb the area. Antibiotics may be prescribed, and you can usually go home the same day.

q: How long does it take for a breast abscess to heal?
a: A breast abscess usually heals completely within a few days or weeks after the pus is drained.

q: Can I breastfeed during treatment for a breast abscess?
a: Yes, you should continue breastfeeding with both breasts if you can. It will not harm your baby and can help your breast heal. If breastfeeding is too painful, you can try expressing milk with your hand or a breast pump.

q: What causes a breast abscess?
a: A breast abscess can form if a breast infection (mastitis) is not treated quickly. It is more common in breastfeeding women, but it can also occur in non-breastfeeding women, although less frequently.

q: What happens if my symptoms do not improve within 2 days of starting antibiotics?
a: If your symptoms do not start to improve within 2 days of starting antibiotics, it is important to go back to the GP for further evaluation and treatment.

q: How can I reduce the risk of getting a breast abscess?
a: Getting prompt treatment for mastitis can help reduce the risk of developing a breast abscess.
